If you have tried both w=
ays and encountered this problem, then great; otherwise, I suggest you resi=
st the temptation to "keep the source simple" at the cost of doing what you=
 need to do. xUnit users often make their test fixtures too complex because=
 they want to adhere to "one test class per production class". The complex =
fixture with 50 tests is more difficult to navigate than five tests with si=
mple fixtures and 10 tests each. This is my experience.

For the book I'm w=
orking on, I have the following three test fixtures for testing Java's Coll=
ection interface.

* BagTest
* EmptyBagTest
* HelloTwiceBagTest

Other than=
 the somewhat obscure "hello twice bag" (a bag with the object "hello" in i=
t twice), I think this is pretty easy to read. Do you find anything in thos=
e names that makes it difficult to understand what's tested where? The alte=
rnative is a bunch of test methods like:

* testEmpty_Empty
* testEmpty_Hel=
loTwice
* testEmpty

A group of these per behavior to test. Such duplicatio=
n is truly unnecessary and having multiple test fixtures is just as easy (i=
f not easier) to read and understand.

Understand that I'm talking about th=
e fear I sense you have about making the test code complex, and not attacki=
ng you or your ideas. The way I see it: either way, it's complex; but I thi=
nk having many fixtures is less complex than one big monolithic fixture. If=
 you favor cohesive production classes (and probably you do), then why not =
cohesive test fixtures?

>If there are too many test classes testing a
>sin=
gle source class, it become difficult to look at a package for the
>first t=
ime and understand what is going on.

It may become difficult, but not if t=
he tests are well named. The same is true for any code: complex code with b=
ad names is difficult to read; complex code with good names is often not-th=
at-difficult to read. Since the complexity is there either way, why not go =
down the path that allows the best names?

 abstract test cases. The benefit is that I can enter a package, look

ed fixtures is not a bad idea at all. I just don't think that it's necessar=
ily any clearer: it's just all in one file rather than in three.
